titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Edwin Martin Photograph Collection
1994-2001
PR 96
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by by Holly Hinman

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from martin.xml

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-08-16T17:02-0400

did.physloc: Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections
did.abstract: The photographs in this collection document stores, store fronts, street vendors, and various tradesmen such as butchers, bakers, and barbers in New York City, mostly in Manhattan.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to thirty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. See guidelines in Print Room for details.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Permission to reproduce any Print Room holdings through publication must be obtained from:
Rights and Reproductions The New-York Historical Society
Two West 77th Street
New York, NY 10024
Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282
Fax: (212) 579-8794

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as Edwin Martin Photograph Collection, PR 096, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Edwin Martin was born in 1943, and educated at Florida State University, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Indiana University. He worked as a news photographer in the mid-1980s, and served as the photo editor for the Newark Star-Ledger from 1999-2000. During the late 1990s, Martin taught in the Department of Journalism and Mass Media at Rutgers University. In addition, Martin was Curator of Photography at the North Carolina State University Visual Arts Center from 1990-1993.

Martin's photographic projects include "Postergirls," photos of public posters, "The Readers," photographs concerning the nature and activity of reading, and "Mud Show," which documents traveling circus shows. His proximity to New York City in the 1990s allowed him to focus on two different portfolios of photographs: "NYNY," and "NY Metier," which both highlight street vendors, storefronts, and street life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Edwin Martin Photograph Collection spans the period from 1994-2001 and contains images from the photographer's portfolios, "NYNY," and "NY Metier." The collection is divided into two series, after the portfolio titles. Photographs document New York City stores, storefronts, street vendors, and various tradesmen such as bakers, butchers, and barbers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is divided into two series, "NYNY" and "NY Metier."

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at the Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections
relatedmaterial.p: Other photographs of street vendors, working people, and storefronts can be found in the Irving Browning Photograph Collection (PR 009) and throughout the Photographer File (PR 050).

controlaccess.subject: Storefronts -- New York (State) -- New York
Stores, Retail -- New York (State) -- New York
Street vendors -- New York (State) -- New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series I includes 61 11x14 silver gelatin prints from the portfolio of the same title. Photographs are arranged alphabetically after the photographer's title. Views show storefronts throughout the city, from Bergdorf Goodman to the Fulton Fish Market.
Photographs are arranged alphabetically according to the photographer's title. General locations of photographs are in brackets.

did.unittitle: Italian Ice [Orchard St. and Houston St.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series II includes 46 11x14 silver gelatin prints from the portfolio of the same title. Photographs are arranged alphabetically after the photographer's title. Several of these photographs show Zito's Bakery, on Bleecker Street, which closed in 2004.
Photographs are arranged alphabetically according to the photographer's title. General locations of photographs are in brackets.
